intro: Phacelia hastata var. dasyphylla, commonly known as the Sierra phacelia, is a perennial flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, branched stems and clusters of small, blue to violet flowers. The leaves are typically lance-shaped and covered in fine pubescence, contributing to its distinctive appearance. This species thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open habitats such as meadows and grasslands. Its nectar-rich flowers attract a variety of pollinators, including bees and butterflies.
